definition: to stagger (times)
mistake/wrong/bad/interlocking/complex/to grind/to polish/to alternate/to stagger/to miss/to let slip/to evade/to inlay with gold or silver
surname Cuo

to open/to start/to turn on/to boil/to write out (a prescription, check, invoice etc)/to operate (a vehicle)/carat (gold)/abbr. for Kelvin, 開爾文|开尔文[Kai1 er3 wen2]/abbr. for 開本|开本[kai1 ben3], book format

sentences.english: When putt in place, the block stones shall be bigger-face up with joints staggered.
sentences.chinese: 摆放块石时，石料应大面向上，缝隙相互错开。

sentences.english: Layered construction, seam position should be staggered with each other.
sentences.chinese: 分层施工时，留缝位置应互相错开。

sentences.english: They planned to stagger our rehearsing hours.
sentences.chinese: 他们打算错开我们的排演时间。

sentences.english: Can consider whether to stagger off the North and the South?
sentences.chinese: 是否可以考虑南北方错开休假？

sentences.english: Both of them were offset by large-sized sinistral move of the Tanlou fault in Mesozoic.
sentences.chinese: 郯庐断裂带中生代大规模左行平移使两者错开。

sentences.english: Screw hollow and motor spindle are distributed staggered and equally.
sentences.chinese: 螺纹安装孔的位置与电装电机轴线成错开对称分布。

sentences.english: To stagger the interfaces of tape and plate.
sentences.chinese: 胶带的介面应与版材的介面错开。

sentences.english: Restaurants and spas staggered hours to reduce staffing.
sentences.chinese: 餐馆和温泉的营业时间相互错开，以便减少人手。

definition: to avoid/to evade/to keep away from
crack/gap between two objects/gap in time between two events
to match up/to coincide
peak period/rush hour
gap/interval/compartment/to divide/to separate/to leave a gap of (two weeks, three meters etc)
to stagger usage to ameliorate peak load
gap (between two objects)/interval of time (between events)/opening in one's schedule/free time/(fig.) gap (in the market etc)
lit. to see a gap and stick in a needle (idiom); fig. to make use of every second and every inch
gap/interval
as much as possible/to the greatest extent
as much as possible/to the greatest extent
neutral gear
to push back (progress, the times etc)
to overlap/to superimpose/to telescope/to run together/to duplicate/one over another/superposition/an overlap/redundancy/reduplication (in Chinese grammar, e.g. 散散步[san4 san4 bu4] to have a stroll)
to crowd in/to cram in/to force others aside/to press/to squeeze/to find (time in one's busy schedule)
to postpone/to defer/to delay
to meet/to hold a meeting
